K. HERA, T. KELETI, AND A. M ATHE
Abstract. We prove that for any 1  k  n and s  1, the union of any
nonempty s-Hausdor dimensional family of k-dimensional ane subspaces
of Rn has Hausdor dimension k + s. More generally, we show that for any
0    k, if B  Rn and E is a nonempty collection of k-dimensional ane
subspaces of Rn such that every P  E intersects B in a set of Hausdor di-
mension at least , then dim B  2  k + min(dim E, 1), where dim denotes
the Hausdor dimension. As a consequence, we generalize the well-known
Furstenberg-type estimate that every -Furstenberg set has Hausdor dimen-
sion at least 2; we strengthen a theorem of Falconer and Mattila [5]; and we
show that for any 0  k  n, if a set A  Rn contains the k-skeleton of a
rotated unit cube around every point of Rn, or if A contains a k-dimensional
ane subspace at a xed positive distance from every point of Rn, then the
Hausdor dimension of A is at least k + 1.
There are several problems gathering around the general principle that an s-
dimensional collection of d-dimensional sets in Rn must have positive measure if
s + d  n and Hausdor dimension s + d if s + d  n, unless the sets have large
intersections. For example, Wol [18, 19] proved that if a planar set B contains a
circle around every point of a Borel set S  R2 of Hausdor dimension s then B
has positive Lebesgue measure provided s  1, and the Hausdor dimension of B
is at least s + 1 when s  1. Most of these problems are only partially solved. The
most famous example is the Kakeya conjecture, which states that every Besicovitch
set (a compact set that contains a unit line segment in every direction) in Rn has
Hausdor dimension n, see e.g [12]. Note that the directions of lines of Rn form a
set of dimension n 1, so the line segments of a Besicovitch set form a collection of
Hausdor dimension at least n  1, so the above principle would indeed imply the
Kakeya conjecture. On the other hand, the following trivial example shows that
this principle cannot be applied for every s-dimensional collection of lines: for any
collection of lines of a xed plane of R3 the union clearly has Hausdor dimension
at most 2, which is less than s + 1 if s  1. In this paper we show that the above
principle holds for any s-dimensional collection of lines or even k-dimensional ane

It is natural to ask what happens if we go further and take the union of -
Hausdor dimensional subsets of an s-dimensional family of k-dimensional ane
subspaces of Rn for some s  1 and   (0, k]. Our most general result (Theo-
rem 2.1) gives that in this case the union has Hausdor dimension at least 2k+s.
Note that this result implies a known Furstenberg-type estimate. Let 0    1
and suppose that F  R2 is a Furstenberg set: a compact set such that for every
e  S1 there is a line Le in direction e for which dim Le  F  , see e.g. [12].
Since the sets Le form an at least 1-dimensional collection of lines of R2 our above

and for every e  S1 there is a line Le in direction e for which dim Le  F   then
dim F  2 1 + s and dim F   + s
2 . So our result is also a generalization of the
rst estimate of Molter and Rela.
Our original motivation comes from the following question: What is the minimal
Hausdor dimension of a set in Rn that contains the k-skeleton of a rotated unit
cube centered at every point of Rn? In [1] it is proved that for every 0  k  n there
exist such sets of Hausdor dimension at most k + 1. As a fairly quick application
of the above results we show (Theorem 2.6) that for every 0  k  n such a set
must have Hausdor dimension at least k + 1, so k + 1 is the minimal Hausdor
dimension. We remark that if we have k-skeletons of rotated and scaled cubes
centered at every point then the minimal Hausdor dimension is k, see [1], and
if we allow only scaled axis-parallel cubes then the minimal Hausdor dimension
is n  1, see [10] for k = 1, n = 2 and [16] for the general case. We also show
(Theorem 2.6) that if A contains a k-dimensional ane subspace at a xed positive
distance from every point of Rn, then the Hausdor dimension of A is at least k + 1.
The paper is organized as follows: In Section 2 we state our most general result
(Theorem 2.1), and prove its corollaries. In Section 3 we prove Theorem 2.1 subject
HAUSDORFF DIMENSION OF UNIONS OF AFFINE SUBSPACES
to a lemma (Lemma 3.7), which will be proved in Sections 4 and 5. In Section 4
we prove a purely geometrical lemma, which will be used during the L2 estimation
procedure in Section 5 to prove Lemma 3.7.

Remark 2.7. In the special cases mentioned in Theorem 2.6, the estimate is sharp.

Remark 2.9. The authors in [1] show that the estimate in Corollary 2.8 is sharp
if dim C = n and S can be covered by a countable union of k-dimensional ane
subspaces that do not contain the origin.
On the other hand, if the covering subspaces contain the origin, then the estimate
is not always sharp. Indeed, if S is a punctured line through the origin and C = Rn,
then A is a Nikodym set, thus the conjecture is dim A = n. The lower bounds
obtained for the dimension of Besicovitch sets give lower bounds for the dimension
of Nikodym sets, thus for dim A as well. A survey of the currently best lower bounds
can be found in [12]. As an example, by [17], dim A  n+2
the bound 2 given by Corollary 2.8 provided n  2.
